segments.text: I believe you left William & Mary in 46 then?
That's correct and I went from there first to back to East Central State College.
Taught there about nine weeks, summer term only.
There I went to University of Oklahoma.

I think probably my contacts while I was there and before, and my contacts in the Texas Academy, Oklahoma Academy in the early days, put me in line for a job with them, and I hadn't anymore, and hit Oklahoma again, and Dr. Richards, head of the Department of Biology, offered me a job, so, and I took it.
What was that job?
I was limnologist for the biological survey, University of Oklahoma Biological Survey.
I did a little teaching in the LD rank of full professor in zoology.
You say you did a little teaching.
Does that imply you did primarily research?
Yes, it was almost all research in limnology.
My correct limnology is the study of the seashore?
No, it's the equivalent of that, but it means the study of aquatic, freshwater aquatic plants.
And I studied lakes and rivers and ponds and what have you all over the state.
It's a beautiful town.
But you only stayed there for one year?
Yes, that's correct.
Dr. Hopkins was responsible for tearing loose from over there.
This Project 9 thing had reared its head and he was put in charge of it and he had to have someone to take over the field work in Louisiana where the study was to be made.

and I didn't really care much about going to Louisiana, living down in the Boone docks, but they made it worth my while financially, and the University of Oklahoma didn't seem to be very much interested in keeping me.
this job.
I took a leave of absence to go, I remained with the University of Oklahoma while I was in Louisiana working on this Project 9.
Had the research work already started when you...
Yes, Dr. Hopkins had organized
part of the elements of it, and the personnel problems were being taken care of by Dr. Doak, who was head of the Department of Biology before I got there.
So I came in probably two or three months or more after the project had been set up by Dr. Hopkins.
but they still had no one to run the field work in Louisiana.
And I know I've heard about Project 9.
Would you tell us what the purpose of this research project was?
what the project was about?
Yes, what was Project 9 all about?
The Project 9 was occasioned by, I think, a concatenation of circumstances.
Primarily, along in 1946 and 7, oystermen began to sue the oil companies.

Now the reason for this suit was that a previous suit against Texaco, which had been tried about ten years prior to that, in the mid-thirties, had been here in the courts all of this time, and it was a pollution suit against Texaco.
Then the state Supreme Court reversed the original ruling, which had been in favor of Texaco, the district court.
As soon as this reversal became known, the Oysterman fell all over themselves to join the bandwagon and sue the oil companies, which they did.
The oil companies, Texaco leading,
organized to have the whole business studied as closely as possible and as extensively as possible and set up project nine.
What was the claim of the oystermen?
You said there was a claim for pollution.
It was purely a pollution claim that the oysters were dying because of toxic effects of oil.
That was their claim, exactly.
The claims amounted to somewhere around $32 million.
I added this up myself.
I have copies of all of the petitions, and I added them up, and that's what they came to.
That was lots of money in those days.
Still is today, in fact.
Still is.
The man who really organized all of this business
and ramrodded it was Dr. Jack, head of the Research Foundation.
I assume that you know about that?
Not a whole lot, no.
I knew that he had headed the Research Foundation initially.
He was the man who really ramrodded the whole business.
A dynamic sort of a man.
An engineer.
and one of the best of the engineer researchers.
His field was bridges.
I've seen his bibliography on suspension bridges.
He was a very fine man to work for and with and he took a great deal of interest in all of everything that went on.
was over in Louisiana, poking his nose into everything, and generally seeing to it that it ran.
Really a job that Dr. Jackula was not fitted for, and I think put him under a great mental strain all of the time.
because he was a researcher and he would prefer to sit in some back office and do his bridge work rather than what he was doing, but he nevertheless did a tremendously good job.
So the oil companies led by Texaco then came to Texas A&M and asked...
Yes, all of them excepting one that were involved and that one was Gulf Oil Company.
carried their own investigations separately.
And we have a man on the faculty who worked with them at the same time.
This is Dr. Sammy Ray at the laboratory at Galveston.
And of course Sammy and I got to know each other at that time.
So their question to, their request to A&M was to investigate the cause of the death of the Western.
That's right.
It was simply to take into consideration every possible cause that could be considered.
That's the way we started out.
I think we eliminated oil before we eliminated anything else.
It was the easiest one of all of them, but it was less than a year before I knew that disease was the cause.
To make a long story short, that's the way it came out.
There were actually three investigations of that
of the mortalities of oysters in Louisiana.
One of them was by Gulf.
Maybe I should say four, because Freeport Sufferer was also accused of all of these things, as well as the oil companies.
They set up a study, and the state of Louisiana set up a study.
The state of Louisiana chose a man conveniently for me and for Dr. Hopkins because they chose a man with whom we had worked together at the Virginia Fisheries Laboratory, Dr. Malcolm Owen.
Dr. Owen had gone from Virginia Fisheries to South Carolina, I believe, and then the state of Louisiana hired him to investigate the same mortalities that we were investigating.
Gulf Oil Company carried on their investigation, and Fleet Force Suffolk carried on theirs, Project 9, all separately.
Three-fourths sulfur has never released any data about their investigations.
They did not investigate disease or anything except in whether or not sulfur was the cause.
The other three came to the same conclusion.
All three of us arrived at exactly the same conclusion that disease was the factor.
and when the original description of the disease came out, this description was a joint paper by the heads of the three groups.
Dr. Rowan, Mr. Collier, now at Florida State, and Project Nine.
How long a term project was this?
I mean, how long did it take to determine this?
The Project 9 project, I was in it for two and a half years, from the middle of 1947 to 1950, January 1950.
It was in January of 1950 that Dr. Jacula talked me into coming to the faculty.
Prior to that, I was with the Research Foundation only.
and then he talked me into joining the newly developed Department of Oceanography, which he was the man who really envisioned this and put it together.
The same man that put together the Project 9.
Now when Project 9 ended,
I guess December the 31st, 1950.
Then the oil companies began another project, which was 23, and I was ahead of that, reduced my staff down to a small number of people.
I had maybe five or six at most, and this is all I needed.
because by that time we knew what was not killing oysters and where to put our efforts and I didn't want these, I didn't want the huge development of that project to start with.
I was against that part of it.
We spent several millions of dollars and
The whole project, if they had turned it over to Dr. Hopkins and me and two or three others, we could have done the whole job for a tenth of what they spent.
Maybe your answer wouldn't have been convincing if you hadn't spent a lot of money on it.
We were accused of hiring all of the experts in the United States on our side.
This was by the oyster mission.
Yeah, of course.

Project 9 was a great project and it was a revelation to me because I had never been paid money, big money, except for the university job I had and that was just a salary for doing research and doing it the way I wanted to.
That's where they spoiled me.
Project 9 you mean?
Yeah.
What was Project 23?
Project 23 was mainly a project which changed its direction.
First, we were continuing studies in these diseases.
We had described this disease, but we didn't really know very much about it, excepting that we did know that it killed oysters, like nobody's business.
But the rest of the story, the biological end of it, is far from being brought to a sufficient close.
we had that problem to finish up.
The other problem, it was a sort of a general problem which had to do with the examination of the operations of the oil companies as a whole, and we pretty abruptly
dropped most of the oil studies in that, but there are so many others, such as the effects of the dredging of canals and the marshlands, an immense number of other things of this sort.
So, we took over these investigations.
That's what we did for about 10 years.
Simply
What it amounted to, the oil companies let me spend as much time as I wanted to on my parasitological problem.
Then I helped them solve their problems in other ways.
The problem of the effect of their operations on the biota and the environment.
Incidentally, on people and other things.
Did you ever track down the source of the disease in the oysters?
The source?
The organism?
Oh yes, since that time I have discovered a half a dozen of other diseases of oysters and have worked with many many people including the federal government

In fact, I set up the first laboratory for the federal government to help them set it up and taught their basic personnel how to go about studying disease problems at laboratories at Oxford and Maryland.
I took a leave of absence from Texas A&M
about in 63, I believe, and spent a summer over there just getting them straightened out so that they could go.
So this later project,
While every once in a while this oil pollution problem would rear its head, and I continued to study it, it was nothing like the primary thing.
The primary thing was mechanical operations of the oil companies.
This meant structures, dredging, all of these things.
I took nearly two years just to study the dredging problem alone.
So you, I believe you said you were involved with Project 23 for about 10 years?
Yes, up until 1960.
Part of that time I lived in Louisiana, five years.
Right after I took, came to the Division of Oceanography as professor of biological oceanography, I came
Director of the Marine Laboratory at Galveston, and I set it up somewhere about 1951 or 2, I've forgotten now exactly when.
I had two graduate students down there at that time, and we were on the campus of the medical school.
They gave us a building down there to do this.
but I didn't stay with that too long.
I couldn't get enough money out of the school to tell the truth about it.
By the school, Texas A&M.
Yeah, that's right it is.
The only money was our own projects.
In other words, I was supposed to support the laboratory from my own projects, which I already had, which I did for a good while.
But
You can't build a laboratory that way.
Let me see if I got this straight.
You became professor of marine biology, I believe you said January 1950.
Yes.
Under sort of the pushing or pulling or whatever of Mr. Jackfield.
That's right.
He is the one who organized the department and supervised the getting of the personnel, the original personnel.
You did that in 50 then, did you first begin offering courses in oceanography in the fall of 50?
I think they had actually organized this before I came back in 50.
It was organized in about 49 and they got Dale Leeper from Scripps and Dr. Price, geologist, I've forgotten.
Oh yeah, Bob Reed was one of the original ones, and that's all of it at that time.
Okay, and so for how long, what I'm not clear on is how long did you teach on campus here?
For the first 10 years, I taught
I actually taught around five years.
And then this thing over in Louisiana got so big that they asked me to come back and stay over there.
So I was still on the campus and still part of the faculty, but I went back to live over there.
I lived there for five years until 1960.
By that time things were centering down again and
so they offered me then the head of the Department of Biology.
I came back in 1960 and took that over, but still retained my arrangement on a different basis with the oil companies.
There was no project as such, but the school, as you know, allows a man to do a certain amount of
consulting work and things of this sort about two days a month or something like that.
So I had an arrangement, an actual agreement in writing with about five or six oil companies to continue this work with them to take care of their problems.
So I continued working with that problem
those problems as they came up and I'm still doing it today.
Only today you can do it on a more frequent basis.
I do it on a more frequent and intense basis now.
At that point where you, during that five years that you lived in Louisiana, that five years between 1950 and 60, had you severed your connections with Texas A&M?
No, I was on the faculty and came back over here every so often for general checkups and realignments and things of this sort.
But my project through the Research Foundation, 23,
simply took over my efforts.
So you were, while you were still on the faculty, you weren't actually teaching any courses?
Graduate students.
I was teaching graduate students all that time and took at least two of them back with me over to Louisiana.
gave them jobs and supervised their theses and dissertations over there.
Do you have any quick recollection of how many theses and dissertations came out of Project 23?
No, I sure don't.
I do know that I have a number of men in pretty high positions.
Al Sparks is some sort of a deputy bureaucrat in the Department of Interior and so on.
Jerry Stein is with the Copley Foundation in California.
I don't remember a lot of others, but I've got them scattered all over there.
Oh yeah, I have two or three of them are
that I had at Grand Isle working for them and now have PhDs and are in state colleges here, either in Louisiana or in Texas.

It appeared to me at one point that it was might have been somewhat odd for you to jump from one department, say oceanography, over to the head of another department, biology, but then you've been always been a biologist.
It didn't make any difference to me whether I was doing biology and oceanography or biology and biology.
It doesn't make any difference to me whether or not there is a department at all.
You mean any kind of department?
Yeah, that's right, any kind of department.
You were head of the biology department for what, 11 years?
No, I believe seven.
Approximately seven.
And about 67, I got to be 65 years old, I believe it was, and of course you can't de-head it, after you get to be 65, so I became a professor of biology at that time.
I ran along until 1970 when I retired.
I mean from the university.
As head of the biology department, did you do any teaching?
Yes.
I taught one freshman course the entire period, most of the period anyway.
This was the freshman invertebrate course.
and also taught at one time or other several graduate courses of various kinds.
The principal of one of these was in the advanced
field of symbiotics.
Symbiotics, the relationships of organisms as disease and mutual associations and things of this sort.
So I did teach all of the time.
I never at any time had less than one course at a time.
Usually I had two
But only the lecture sections in the freshman course, the laboratories.
These are the type where you have 200 students and you walk in and throw it at them.
Three days a week.
That's right.
They still have four hours of lab sometimes.
They may have the four hours in the lab.
I presume also you continue to direct graduate students in the theses and dissertations?
Yes, throughout all of it.
When I quit as head of department, I think I had about 10 or 12 graduate students at that time.
I began cutting them down about that time, but I never really got through with all of them until about two or three years after I retired.
Well, I would think that would be quite a load in itself to have 10 or 12 graduate students working on projects.
It's supposed to be about three times a full-time job.
I didn't find it that way at all.
I could have taken that many more.
Well, I'm sure a lot depends upon the students you have and the type of projects on which they're working.
And the way you manage them.
Some people can't take one graduate student to do it right.
But it depends on who you are.
Dr. Hopkins, keep track of all of them.
It doesn't make much difference how many he has.
